item.title: A toy engine. From 0 to Ludum Dare
item.description: Last November I started working on a toy DX12 renderer. At first my intention was to add a new backend for Milton, but after I got the first triangle going it became pretty addictive to just keep going and see where I could take it. Here’s a write-up of what I’ve got going! As I have grown this system, my main focus has been on API design and the core rendering API.

item.title: The current state of my compiler project
item.description: This is the second post about my C compiler, SCC. Look here for an index. In the past couple of months I have been working on the compiler fairly regularly, in manageable 30-40 minute intervals about every day or so, and it has gotten to the point where I know that I can get a working C compiler by just putting in the hours. This project has been like drinking from a firehose.

item.title: I'm making a compiler!
item.description: This is the first post about my C compiler, SCC. Look here for an index. It’s been almost 3 months since I joined Intel as a BIOS developer. I like it here, and mostly I’m relieved that later this year I will celebrate my 30th birthday and not be living in my parent’s house. Not that there’s anything wrong with that, but my sense of self-worth was starting to get hit because I was not being a productive member of the economy.

item.title: How the Milton Renderer Works
item.description: Disclaimer: This document is not up-to-date. I will eventually write a new post that better reflects the current state of Milton, but in the mean time this is good enough. After a long time in development, Milton has a brand new renderer. Before now, Milton did all of its rendering on the CPU. The new renderer uses OpenGL to take advantage of the GPU. I didn’t expect to release OpenGL without problems.
